section.title: Planned Maintenance for a Compute Node
section.para: If one or more of your compute nodes needs hardware maintenance and you can schedule a planned maintenance then this procedure should be followed.

section.title: Performing planned maintenance on a compute node
section.para: If you have planned maintenance to perform on a compute node, you have to take it offline, repair it, and restart it. To do so, follow these steps:

step.para: Obtain the hostname for your compute node, which you will use in subsequent commands when <hostname> is requested:
The following example shows two compute nodes:
step.screen: $ openstack host list | grep compute | ardana-cp1-comp0001-mgmt | compute | AZ1 | | ardana-cp1-comp0002-mgmt | compute | AZ2 |

step.para: Disable provisioning on the compute node, which will prevent additional instances from being spawned on it:

note.para: Make sure you re-enable provisioning after the maintenance is complete if you want to continue to be able to spawn instances on the node. You can do this with the command:

step.para: At this point you have two choices:

listitem.para: Live migration: This option enables you to migrate the instances off the compute node with minimal downtime so you can perform the maintenance without risk of losing data.

Stop/start the instances: Issuing openstack server stop commands to each of the instances will halt them. This option lets you do maintenance and then start the instances back up, as long as no disk failures occur on the compute node data disks. This method involves downtime for the length of the maintenance.

step.para: If you choose the live migration route, See for more details. Skip to step #6 after you finish live migration.
If you choose the stop start method, continue on.

listitem.para: List all of the instances on the node so you can issue stop commands to them:
Issue the openstack server stop command against each of the instances:
Confirm that the instances are stopped. If stoppage was successful you should see the instances in a SHUTOFF state, as shown here:

Do your required maintenance. If this maintenance does not take down the disks completely then you should be able to list the instances again after the repair and confirm that they are still in their SHUTOFF state:
Start the instances back up using this command:
listitem.screen: $ openstack server start ef31c453-f046-4355-9bd3-11e774b1772f Request to start server ef31c453-f046-4355-9bd3-11e774b1772f has been accepted.

listitem.para: Confirm that the instances started back up. If restarting is successful you should see the instances in an ACTIVE state, as shown here:
If the openstack server start fails, you can try doing a hard reboot:
If this does not resolve the issue you may want to contact support.
